subject: RE: [junit] Best Practice for Tests ?
msgSnippet: ... It isn t a question of being favorable or not.  It is a question of Do you want to automate the testing of your GUI with JUnit?  And if so, to what
messageBody:
> Thank you. Well, most probably I was not clear. I'm sorry
> for that. I'll try
> again:
>
> After testing the model, I like to do integration tests
> for model, control
> and view. I do this by checking the view. But as the view
> is used by users
> only, there is no need to know state, at least for
> programm components other
> than the tests. This approach is (Did I get you right
> now?) not favorable in
> your eyes? Which would be your favorable approach?

It isn't a question of being favorable or not. It is a question of "Do you
want to automate the testing of your GUI with JUnit? And if so, to what
granularity?" I think testing the GUI is always good, but there are
limitations for JUnit to do this. If there is pertinent state information
that you want to capture (which it doesn't sound like there is) you can use
the approach I mentioned before. If you simply want to test the overall
look, a one-eyed inspection is fine. If you want to programmatically test
the overall look, something like SilkTest would probably be a good way to
go. I think that having state inspectors on every GUI component is
overkill! If there is some meta-state that your controller gets from the
view to effect a change on your model, then write an inspector on your
controller for that, but not just for testing. The test should reflect (to
some degree) the usage. Again, this isn't a silver bullet, it's just one
example.

MVC can be difficult. If it is done improperly it offers many traps!! But
done rightly, it's a wonderful tool. Testing is easier, refactoring is
easier, etc.

-Jason
